items.synopsis: Marjorie identified as a woman, but was put in with men in Tasmania's Risdon Prison. Eventually, she refused treatment for an illness and died. Now, her family wants an investigation — saying authorities knew she was at risk of abuse.

title.children: 'They're killing me, mum': Marjorie was in a men's prison for years. Then she died

image.altText: One two Israeli women who were Israel Palestinians Hostages

items.synopsis: The two freed hostages who were released by Hamas have landed in Tel Aviv, Israel, with footage showing soldiers carrying the women on stretchers from a helicopter into Ichilov hospital. Follow live.

title.children: Freed hostages arrive at Israel medical facility, UN calls for return of remaining hostages and urgent ceasefire

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Israeli bombardments across the Gaza Strip have intensified "three-fold" compared to previous days, says the latest UN update. The UN's Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs says the deadliest attacks in the last 24 hours included "several airstrikes on residential buildings in Jabalia Refugee Camp" and in northern Gaza. "Furthermore, in the last 24 hours, two UNRWA installations, one in Al Bureij camp and the other in Nuseirat in the middle area, sustained collateral damage due to airstrikes in the surrounding areas of these facilities," the report said. The estimated death toll among Palestines has now surpassed 5,000 according to the Palestinian Ministry of Health.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israel's air strikes in Gaza intensify 'three-fold', says UN

children.content: Israeli bombardments across the Gaza Strip have intensified "three-fold" compared to previous days, says the latest UN update.

The UN's Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs says the deadliest attacks in the last 24 hours included "several airstrikes on residential buildings in Jabalia Refugee Camp" and in northern Gaza.

"Furthermore, in the last 24 hours, two UNRWA installations, one in Al Bureij camp and the other in Nuseirat in the middle area, sustained collateral damage due to airstrikes in the surrounding areas of these facilities," the report said.
The estimated death toll among Palestines has now surpassed 5,000 according to the Palestinian Ministry of Health.

props.alt: A graph showing the number of israeli and palestinian casualties

children.content: (United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Jerusalem-based politician and doctor, Mustafa Barghouti, says Hamas is ready to release more hostages, particularly those holding dual citizenship. Dr Barghouti, who founded the Palestine National Initiative party, told ABC Radio Melbourne said he does not believe Hamas is asking for a prisoner exchange deal. "They have no interest in keeping civilians and that's why they are ready to release them," he said. "They are now negotiating with the Red Cross about how to safely pass them so they can go to Egypt … or they can go wherever they want. "We were informed very clearly that they are about to release 50 more." Dr Barghouti called for a ceasefire in Gaza and said around 20 of the hostages taken by Hamas on October 7 had been killed by Israeli bombing.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Jerusalem-based politician says Hamas wants to release more hostages

children.content: Jerusalem-based politician and doctor, Mustafa Barghouti, says Hamas is ready to release more hostages, particularly those holding dual citizenship.
Dr Barghouti, who founded the Palestine National Initiative party, told ABC Radio Melbourne said he does not believe Hamas is asking for a prisoner exchange deal.

props.alt: a man wearing a suit and glasses looking into the camera

children.content: Mustafa Barghouti says Hamas is not interested in keeping civilian hostages
(ABC News)
"They have no interest in keeping civilians and that's why they are ready to release them," he said.
"They are now negotiating with the Red Cross about how to safely pass them so they can go to Egypt … or they can go wherever they want.
"We were informed very clearly that they are about to release 50 more."
Dr Barghouti called for a ceasefire in Gaza and said around 20 of the hostages taken by Hamas on October 7 had been killed by Israeli bombing.

image.altText: Two women look at a share price board outside the ASX in Sydney.

items.synopsis: Australian stocks are off to a better-than-expected start, while RBA governor Michele Bullock will deliver her first prepared speech tonight. Follow the latest updates in our live blog.

title.children: ASX edges up, Wall Street ended mixed, gold and oil slip

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Michele Bullock will deliver her first prepared address as RBA governor on "Monetary Policy in Australia: Complementarities and Trade-offs" at CBA's Global Markets Conference in Sydney at 7pm AEDT. NAB has noted the recent Minutes and last week's fireside chat "were more hawkish and plays to the view the RBA hiking rates if Q3 CPI on Wednesday prints above their August SoMP forecasts". The key messaging from the fireside chat was that inflation was proving sticky. "There's a few things that are suggestive that it's going to be difficult to get inflation down" and "services inflation — inflation in things like takeaways, hairdressers, restaurants, those sorts of things — that inflation is running at a bit over 4 per cent ... so it's above our target and it's pretty sticky". NAB added the RBA Minutes also showed limited tolerance for an upside inflation surprise. "The Board has a low tolerance for a slower return of inflation to target than currently expected." Ms Bullock will speak again on Thursday.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Michele Bullock to give her first prepared address

children.content: Michele Bullock will deliver her first prepared address as RBA governor on "Monetary Policy in Australia: Complementarities and Trade-offs" at CBA's Global Markets Conference in Sydney at 7pm AEDT.
NAB has noted the recent Minutes and last week's fireside chat "were more hawkish and plays to the view the RBA hiking rates if Q3 CPI on Wednesday prints above their August SoMP forecasts".
The key messaging from the fireside chat was that inflation was proving sticky.

"There's a few things that are suggestive that it's going to be difficult to get inflation down" and "services inflation — inflation in things like takeaways, hairdressers, restaurants, those sorts of things — that inflation is running at a bit over 4 per cent ... so it's above our target and it's pretty sticky".
NAB added the RBA Minutes also showed limited tolerance for an upside inflation surprise.
"The Board has a low tolerance for a slower return of inflation to target than currently expected."
Ms Bullock will speak again on Thursday.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian share market is off to a better-than-expected start this morning, helped by financial and mining stocks. The ASX 200 was up 25 points or 0.4 per cent, to 6,869, by 10:15am AEDT. Healthcare, utilities and industrials were the only sectors that were in the red. Here are the top and bottom movers at open.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX edges up at open

children.content: The Australian share market is off to a better-than-expected start this morning, helped by financial and mining stocks.
The ASX 200 was up 25 points or 0.4 per cent, to 6,869, by 10:15am AEDT.
Healthcare, utilities and industrials were the only sectors that were in the red.
Here are the top and bottom movers at open.
(Reuters)
(Reuters)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: As the Gaza-Israel war continues, a leading global strategist says the only issue is how bad it gets. Rabobank global strategist Michael Every has modelled three scenarios and the likely impacts on markets. The first involves the war continuing between Israel and Hamas; the second sees it expand to include Lebanon, Syria, Jordan and Egypt; while the third may see the likes of Iran, Saudi Arabia and other Gulf nations getting involved. Mr Every told The Business's Kirsten Aiken in some of these scenarios, oil prices could reach a minimum of $US150 a barrel and the world should expect higher inflation.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ICYMI: How badly will war in the Middle East impact economies?

children.content: As the Gaza-Israel war continues, a leading global strategist says the only issue is how bad it gets.
Rabobank global strategist
Michael Every
has modelled three scenarios and the likely impacts on markets.

The first involves the war continuing between Israel and Hamas; the second sees it expand to include Lebanon, Syria, Jordan and Egypt; while the third may see the likes of Iran, Saudi Arabia and other Gulf nations getting involved.
Mr Every told The Business's
Kirsten Aiken
in some of these scenarios, oil prices could reach a minimum of $US150 a barrel and the world should expect higher inflation.
